abstract.p: Distortion is a major problem when using charge-coupled device cameras. This study developed a novel adaptive calibration method for minimizing camera distortion. The proposed method improves the calibration of the camera when solving the problems of radial distortion, decentering distortion and prism distortion. Tracking results are also enhanced. Additionally, the proposed method does not require complex mathematical equations to calibrate the camera, so the camera can be calibrated in real-time. Simulation and experimental comparisons with conventional methods confirm the good performance of the proposed method.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Methods of using machine vision to track objects in three-dimensional (3D) space have developed rapidly in recent years. Information about 3D objects can be obtained by calculating geometric relationships between two-dimensional (2D) images from two properly arranged CCDs. However, the image distortion by the CCD may affect the precision of the 2D images. Therefore, CCD calibration to correct pixels distorted by the camera is an important research area in machine vision.

Conrady first developed the decentering distortion model in 1919. In 1966, Brown proposed the well-known Brown–Conrady model, which corrected radial and tangential distortions based on Conrady’s study. However, the CCD distortions include radial distortion, decentering distortion and prism distortion, and the most common distortions are those arising from asymmetry in the photographic lens, i.e., radial distortion - typically be classified as either Barrel distortion or Pincushion distortion. Therefore, many studies, including Park and Hong (2001), Balasubramanian et al. (2009), Wang et al. (2010) and Zhang and Sharf (2011) have discussed radial distortion only to calibrate CCDs and have simplified the distortion model to save computation in real-time applications. However, the methods have not performed well. The method in He and Lic (2008) showed good performance in reducing radial distortion, but the time needed to calibrate the CCDs was much slower than that in real-time control applications. Therefore, besides the accuracy of image, the computing time needed for calibration is the key consideration in real-time applications of image processing by machine vision.

Generally, a distortion model of image by CCDs can be expressed as: (1)xd=x+δx(x,y), yd=y+δy(x,y) where x and y are the ideal image coordinates in 2D image coordinates and where xd and yd are the coordinates with distortion. The δx(x,y) and δy(x,y), which represent the distortion, are composed of three parts, where (2)δ*(x,y)=δ*r(x,y)+δ*d(x,y)+δ*p(x,y), *∈{x,y}δ*r, δ*d and δ*p represent radial distortion, decentering distortion and prism distortion, respectively. Radial distortion results form a flawed radial curvature of the lens and can be expressed as (3)δxr=x·(k1·r2+k2·r4+…), (4)δyr=y·(k1·r2+k2·r4+…) where k1, k2… are the radial distortion coefficients and r2 = x2 + y2. Decentering distortion also results from lens decentering and can be expressed as (5)δxd=p1·(3x2+y2)+2p2·x·y, (6)δyd=p2·(3x2+y2)+2p1·x·y where p1 and p2 are the decentering distortion coefficients. Finally, prism distortion, which arises mainly from lens tilt, can be represented as (7)δxp=s1·r2, δyp=s2·r2 where s1 and s2 are the prism distortion coefficients.

In general, high order terms which are usually negligible for the respective coefficient, do not cause the distortion, shown in Wang et al. (2008), so the radial distortion model is ordered as δxr=x·k1·r2, and δyr=y·k1·r2. Where q1=s1+p1, q2=s2+p2, the distortion model of the CCD image is (8)δx(x,y)=x·k1·r2+q1·r2+x(p1·x+p2·y) (9)δy(x,y)=y·k1·r2+q2·r2+y(p2·x+p1·y).

The proposed method efficiently corrects distortion δx(x,y) and δy(x,y) in real-time. The method has several advantages, such as use of simple calibration formulas to reduce computation time and to compensate for various distortions, including radial, decentering and prism distortions. An adaptive method based on the modified least mean square (LMS) algorithm is also developed to tune the free parameters for computing the camera calibration. Comparisons with the conventional method in Zhang et al. (2003) are also presented.

This paper is organized as follows. Section 2 reveals the proposed adaptive calibration method. Section 3 compares experimental results and simulation results for camera calibration error between the conventional and proposed methods. Finally, Section 4 concludes the study.

sec.title: 2. Adaptive calibration method
sec.p:
The image coordinates and global coordinates in a CCD camera can be represented by (10)xd=f·xiz, yd=f·yiz where xi and yi are the image pixel by CCD, xd and yd denote the practical image coordinates, z is the distance from camera to object, and f is the focal length of CCD. However, the practical coordinates xd and yd include radial distortion, decentering distortion and prism distortion, which differ from the ideal image coordinates xr and yr. Therefore, Figure 1 shows how image coordinates are calibrated to reduce the error. The inverse-distortion model in Ahmed and Farag (2005) used for calibration can be expressed as (11)xc=xd+δxd(xd,yd) and (12)yc=yd+δyd(xd,yd) where xc and yc are the corrected image coordinates after calibration, also called inverse-distortion coordinates. The δxd(xd,yd) and δyd(xd,yd) can be expressed by (13)δxd(xd,yd)=xd·kd1·rd2+qd1·rd2 +xd(pd1·xd+pd2·yd) and (14)δyd(xd,yd)=yd·kd1·rd2+qd2·rd2 +yd(pd2·xd+pd1·yd). To calculate the error between the ideal coordinate and corrected coordinate, ex and ey are defined as (15)ex=xr-xc, ey=yr-yc. Figure 1.
Using adaptive algorithm to adjust the calibration system.
An adaptive method is then used to adjust the calibration to minimize errors ex and ey.

Computing the distortion coordinates xd and yd generate the initial inverse-distortion coefficients kd1, qd1, qd2, pd1, pd2, which are used obtain the corrected coordinates xc and yc. Suppose the lowercase “(i)” of corrected coordinates xc(i),yc(i) denote the ith runtime for the time sequence i=1,2,3,…. The coefficients of the inverse-distortion model can be adjusted by defining ex(i)=xr(i)-xc(i) and ey(i)=yr(i)-yc(i). The calibration formula is defined as (16)kd1(i+1)=kd1(i)+η·∂(ex(i)2+ey(i)2)∂kd1(i)·(xd(i)+yd(i)) where η is the learning rate. Additionally, (17)∂(ex(i)2+ey(i)2)∂kd1(i)=2·ex(i)·∂ex(i)∂kd1(i)+2·ey(i)·∂ey(i)∂kd1(i).
Since the error is (18)ex(i)=xr(i)-xc(i)=xr(i)-xd(i)-δxd(xd(i),yd(i)) there follows (19)∂(ex(i)2+ey(i)2)∂kd1(i)=-2·ex(i)·xd(i)(xd(i)2+yd(i)2) -2·ey(i)·yd(i)(xd(i)2+yd(i)2)
Therefore, (20)∂(ex(i)2+ey(i)2)∂kd1(i)=-2(xd(i)·ex(i)+yd(i)·ey(i)) ×(xd(i)2+yd(i)2).

The other coefficients in the calibration system can be also updated using the following equations: (21)qd1(i+1)=qd1(i)-2·η·ex(i)(xd(i)2+yd(i)2)·xd(i) (22)qd2(i+1)=qd2(i)-2·η·ey(i)(xd(i)2+yd(i)2)·yd(i) (23)pd1(i+1)=pd1(i)-2·η·(ex(i)·xd(i)2+ey(i)·xd(i)·yd(i))xd(i) (24)pd2(i+1)=pd2(i)-2·η·(ey(i)·xd(i)2+ex(i)·xd(i)·yd(i))yd(i).

sec.title: 3. Simulation and experimental results
sec.p:
Here, a set of 7*7 ideal coordinates is generated to test the performance of the proposed method. In the simulations, the runtime is 200, and the learning rate is η = 0.002. The initial weights of the adaptive algorithm are chosen randomly within the range [−1 1]. The calibration performance by both the proposed method and cross-ratio method are presented. In Figure 2, the circles are ideal image coordinates, and the stars are distortion image coordinates in the distortion model obtained by equations (8) and (9). Linking the stars in blue lines shows that distortion increases with distance from the origin. Figure 2.
The distortion configuration.

Figure 3 shows that the calibration results obtained by the cross-ratio method in Zhang et al. (2003) are clearly unsatisfactory. Even at a position far from the origin, the distortion is still substantial because the distance to the origin affects the calibration. Therefore, the cross-ratio method provides good calibration performance within the origin point, but not when the position is far from origin. Additionally, the total distortion in Figure 2 shows that cross-ratio method is only effective for radial distortion. Figure 3.
Calibration of cross-ratio method.

Figure 4 shows the calibration results obtained by the proposed adaptive method. The proposed method clearly improves the calibration by adjusting all coefficients, enhancing the cross-ratio method. In Figure 4, almost all stars are in the circles. In the cross-ratio method, some stars are outside of the circles, especially at the corners of the image. Figure 4.
Calibration of proposed method.

Figure 5 show the error reduction achieved by the proposed method. The vertical axis is defined by summing the squares of errors in the X- and Y-axes of all 49 points in Figure 2, and the horizontal axis shows the runtime. Clearly, the proposed method substantially reduces errors. The residual square error for all points is 2.797 for the proposed method and 33.16 for the cross-ratio method (Figure 5 and Table 1). Additionally, correcting the coefficients with the proposed adaptive method requires about 0.09 seconds for 100 runtimes. However, the computation time required by the conventional method in Ahmed and Farag (2005) is about 4.8 seconds, which is far slower. Figure 5.
The total square errors of the proposed method.

The performance of the proposed method was also tested using webcam images. After obtaining the image coordinates, the coordinates were transformed to global coordinates using equation (10). Figure 6 shows the webcam results, which show that the distance between the points on the paper is 2.5 cm. Figure 6.
The captured image from webcam.

Figure 7 shows the results after transformation to global coordinates. The circles represent the practical position of each point, and the red stars show the webcam coordinates. Figure 7 shows the distortion error between the ideal and actual coordinates after linking the red stars with blue lines. Figure 7.
The distortion image coordinates.

Figure 8 shows the calibration results for distortion image coordinates. Comparison of Figures 7 and 8 shows that the method can still compensate for distortion. The total square errors are 3.1 before correction and 1.43 after correction, shown in Figure 9. The runtime in the experiment increases due to the nonlinearity of real image distortion. The experiments therefore confirm the effectiveness of the proposed method. Figure 8.
The calibration result of proposed method. Figure 9.
The total square errors of experiment.

sec.title: 4. Conclusion
sec.p: The two features of the proposed adaptive calibration method of correcting camera lens distortion are precise calibration coordinates and short computation time. The proposed method can adjust all coefficients to improve the calibration without complex calibration procedures. Additionally, the simple calibration formulas minimize computing effort, which simplifies implementation.
